Provide Feature Contests

Penn, St. John's and Swarthmore

Eight contests will be staged by
the championship Hopkins lacrosse
team this spring. Manager J. G.
Carroll has arranged an attractive
but difficult schedule 'for the Jay
stick-wielders which will probably
give them a clear title to another
championship if it is completed
Without a loss.
The only disappointment from
the standpoint of Hopkins rooters
is that Syracuse has no place on
the schedule. At the meeting of
the Intercollegiate Athletic.Association in New York, the Orange asked
Hopkins for a home and, home
agreement. They were offered
April 14 as a date for the game,
but were unable to accept. Similarly, the Black and Blue could not
accept the offer of Syracuse for a
game April 21, as the University
of Pennsylvania will be met on that
date.
Dartmouth First

The teams to be played on the
first two Saturdays of the season,
April 7 and April 14, have not been
definitely -decided upon, but they
Will probably be Dartmouth and
Virginia. Many colleges are desirous of playing Hopkins on these
days and the lacrosse authorities
have had considerable difficulty in
choosing the most suitable opponents. Dartmouth, however, since
the Green lacrossemen are taking
a Southern trip during the Easter
holidays, has secured a tentative
date for April 7 and Virginia seems
to be favored for the next weekend. This is the first year that
Dartmouth has had a lacrosse team
and they are particularly anxious to
derive some experience from, meeting the Jay twelve. Princeton has
been trying for one of these two
early dates and may succeed in arranging a meeting.

ENGINEERING HALLS
RETAIN OLD NAMES
Mechanical Engineering and
Civil Engineering Halls will
still retain their prosaic designations, it was learned from
the President's office. The
fact that the name of the
Chemical Laboratory Building
has been changed to Remsen
Hall will not cause a revision
in the names of the other
buildings on the campus.
Agitations have been made
at various times to rename the
three scientific buildings,
which finally led to the trustees' action in affixing the
famous chemist's name to
"Chem Lab."

Physics Professors
Go to Conferences
Scientific conferences will be attended by members of the Physics
faculty during the holidays. Dr.
Wood, with Dr. Hubbard and Dr.
Herzfeld, all of the Physics Department, will attend a conference
at Tuxedo Park, N. Y. About seventy scientists will assemble there to
discuss atomic physics. The conference will be opened by Dr. 3.
Franck, who is coming from the
University of Gottingen for that
purpose.
The American Association for the
Advancement of Science is also
holding a meeting at Nashville,
Tenn. Dr. Livingston, of the biological department here at Hopkins,
is secretary of the Association. Dr.
Pfund, of the physics department,
is going to Pittsburgh for Christmas and from there to Nashville,
where he will attend the conference.

FACULTY MEMBERS
ATTEND MEETINGS
Economics, Political Science
and History Men to Go
to Washington
Members of the Economics, Political Science and History departments will attend national meetings
in their various fields during the
holidays. By a coincidence the
meetings which are to be attended
are all holding their sessions in
Washington.
The entire faculty of the Economics department will attend the
meeting of the American Economics Association, to be held in the
national capital on December 27-30.
The main subject of discussions on
the four days will be "The Bane
and Boon of Rising Prices." The
advantages and disadvantages arising from the rising level in prices
will he analyzed.

THE TRAFFIC SITUATION
Can anyone suggest a satisfactory solution to the Homewood
traffic problem? If you think you have a feasible plan for better-.
ing traffic conditions on the campus, please send the plan to the
NEWS-LETTER, and we shall try to have the situation remedied.
The road behind the engineering buildings has, we believe, definitely proved unsatisfactory. It apparently cannot be kept in
repair, no matter how many coats of ashes are poured upon it.
Several hundred automobiles use it every day, and the lower section is rendered even more rough by the trucks that carry building
materials to the new Art Gallery. It has been maintained that if
automobilists will drive slowly and carefully, there should be no
cause to complain, but no matter how slowly he drives, he cannot
avoid the terrific strain on his poor springs and shock absorbers.
One of the instructors actually broke a spring last month.
President Goodnow believes that reopening the road from Gilman Hall to the Barn would be unsafe to pedestrian traffic because
of the narrowness of the road; to widen it or to rebuild in concrete
the one behind the engineering buildings is out of the question
because there are no available funds.
The present arrangement has provoked innumerable complaints
from both the students and members of the faculty. The President
has stated, in reply to inquiries concerning the matter, that the
campus is not a speedway, and that if a reasonable speed were
maintained by the motorists, there would be no cause for complaint. This, we believe, has been disproved by the almost universal dissatisfaction with the scheme now in use.
It does no good, however, mp-ely to complain. Surely, some
one should be able to suggest a better plan—perhaps a system of
reopening the old road and restricting the traffic to one direction.
If you have any ideas on the subject, we invite you to let us know.

Thoughts while pretending to do Christmas shopping.
Strange—the number of intelligently lazy people affected by
this "give and get" bug—there goes a lad who, under normal
circumstances, would be curled up in a comfortable chair with—
well, that doesn't matter; now, under the insidious influence of
this wide-spread disposition toward a somewhat inane merriment,
he is shoving and pushing, and grabbing at this because it's
cheaper than that, and smiling with all the beatific benevolence
of Scrooge after his siege of nightmares. . . Poor shop goils!
. . . Wearily repeated sentences of unreal and unconvincing
politeness. Dutifully, I pity the shop girls. . . . Particularly the Jewesses; it would be bad enough to slave like that if
you could, in case of necessity, convince yourself that the thing
was worth the (Christmas) candle; but this unlovely panic, when
it lacks even the conventional excuse of religious fervor, must be
revolting as well as enervating. . . It would be cruel, n'est-ce
pas, to snatch the dingy beard from one of these Salvation Santas
as he pretended to jot down the name of little Paul Petzel.
Tough on little Paul, perhaps, but .why, if there must be legends
for children, cannot the figures of these legends be represented
as containing some elements of loveliness? Either the imposture
of Salvation Army beggars should be forbidden, or all mammas
should make clear to the children the fraud. . . If I ever have
a child that can respect a myth with a beard like that, I shall
straight-way disown both the child and Santa.
. . . Look out, Bozo, you're drunk !" . . . Good way
to be, such weather. . . . Funny if all the Santa Clauses should
get thoroughly blotto, and really act their parts. . . . I like this
old bird's spirit. If cars won't pause long enough for him to
get across, he retorts to each insolent warning with an exact and
inspired echo. 'Toot' you say? 'Toot yourself, 'n see if yull
like it!' Honk, honk! Go on, Lizzie!" The fact that his nose is
running rather adds to his fascination. The moisture either has
frozen, or will drop any moment now. I wonder. . . By God,
it is an icicle!
Push, shove, scuffle, snort. . . . Tinny piano. "Bye-bye,
pretty baby." Or is it "buy-buy ?" . . . Terrific waft of
cheap perfume, having nothing in common with this mad mob
movement; it contains some subtle suggestion of more or less
cemmercially amorous summer evenings. Perfumes, or perhaps,
all smells, are more thrillingly reminiscent than any other sense
stimuli. There's a line of Marcel Proust's, about the recollections aroused by the taste of a cake dipped in tea; he could make
much of this cheap, gaudy odor, and its associations. . . . It is
enjoyable to give to strangers the names they should possess. . . .
Hers would be Claudette. That's probably because I remember
the legs of Claudette Colbert in "The Kiss in a Taxi." Such legs!
Generous old Santa Claus!
I regret the loss of the old thrill of incessant insistent ringing
of bells; I'm sorry the stacked gold of oranges, the sensual appeal
of very Bacchic purple grapes, the shivery, unappetizing appearance of naked, ungraceful fowl, the smells of nuts and figs, has
no more hold on me; I regret the obsolete tradition of mistletoe.
and the trite propriety of red and green holly. . . . These
people buying and selling food are much healthier than their department-store confreres. Red hands and faces, raw red meat.
white cold counters, white aprons—these people are convincingly
colored. They are actually exciting! How the damned bells
ring! Dusk. Swooping mysterious motor cars, laden—perhaps
with happiness. Inane merriment. . . . I enjoy it. And here
goes my allowance. .

THE TRAFFIC SITUATION
Can anyone suggest a satisfactory solution to the Homewood
traffic problem? If you think you have a feasible plan for better-.
ing traffic conditions on the campus, please send the plan to the
NEWS-LETTER, and we shall try to have the situation remedied.
The road behind the engineering buildings has, we believe, definitely proved unsatisfactory. It apparently cannot be kept in
repair, no matter how many coats of ashes are poured upon it.
Several hundred automobiles use it every day, and the lower section is rendered even more rough by the trucks that carry building
materials to the new Art Gallery. It has been maintained that if
automobilists will drive slowly and carefully, there should be no
cause to complain, but no matter how slowly he drives, he cannot
avoid the terrific strain on his poor springs and shock absorbers.
One of the instructors actually broke a spring last month.
President Goodnow believes that reopening the road from Gilman Hall to the Barn would be unsafe to pedestrian traffic because
of the narrowness of the road; to widen it or to rebuild in concrete
the one behind the engineering buildings is out of the question
because there are no available funds.
The present arrangement has provoked innumerable complaints
from both the students and members of the faculty. The President
has stated, in reply to inquiries concerning the matter, that the
campus is not a speedway, and that if a reasonable speed were
maintained by the motorists, there would be no cause for complaint. This, we believe, has been disproved by the almost universal dissatisfaction with the scheme now in use.
It does no good, however, mp-ely to complain. Surely, some
one should be able to suggest a better plan—perhaps a system of
reopening the old road and restricting the traffic to one direction.
If you have any ideas on the subject, we invite you to let us know.
